executiveSummary.overview: AAVA 2.0 represents a significant structural evolution from AAVA 1.0, introducing hierarchical organization and enhanced metadata while preserving core semantic meaning. The migration shows strong semantic alignment (92%) with moderate structural changes (78%) and excellent technical correctness (98%).
majorDifferences: Structural reorganization from flat array to hierarchical object model
Introduction of workFlowDetail container with explicit ID and name separation
Agent metadata enhancement with agentId and modelDeploymentName fields
Removal of tools array in favor of toolReferences array
Renaming of core fields (workflowId->id, workflowName->name, agentName->name)
risks: Breaking changes for systems expecting flat 'nodes' array structure
Tool reference mechanism change may impact tool resolution logic
Field name changes require mapping updates in dependent systems
executiveSummary.overallAssessment: AAVA 2.0 represents a well-structured evolution that improves metadata organization and clarity while maintaining semantic integrity. Migration requires careful handling of structural changes but offers improved maintainability.

semanticSimilarity.analysis: Both versions represent the same fundamental workflow concept with three identical agents performing the same business functions. Core semantic meaning is preserved across the evolution.
findings: Workflow concept remains identical - data integration specification workflow
All three agents (Technical Specification, Delta Model Changes, Functional Test Cases) preserved with same business purpose
Agent descriptions are character-for-character identical, ensuring semantic consistency
Task definitions and expected outputs maintain complete semantic alignment
Business logic and process flows unchanged between versions
deductions: 8-point deduction for structural field name changes that may cause semantic confusion during migration (workflowId vs id, agentName vs name)
lineReferences: Lines 2-3 (AAVA 1.0) vs Lines 2-5 (AAVA 2.0): Workflow identification preserved but restructured
Lines 6-8 (AAVA 1.0) vs Lines 8-10 (AAVA 2.0): Agent naming convention changed but semantic meaning preserved

structuralSimilarity.analysis: AAVA 2.0 introduces significant structural improvements through hierarchical organization while maintaining core data relationships. The evolution represents a modernization of the metadata schema.
findings: Root structure evolution: flat properties to hierarchical workFlowDetail container
Agent organization: 'nodes' array renamed to 'workflowAgents' with enhanced metadata
Field standardization: consistent naming patterns (id, name) across entities
Metadata enhancement: addition of agentId and modelDeploymentName fields
Tool reference modernization: tools array replaced with toolReferences structure
deductions: 22-point deduction for significant structural reorganization requiring migration logic
Breaking changes in array structure and field naming conventions
lineReferences: Lines 8-10 (AAVA 1.0): tools array -> Line 12 (AAVA 2.0): toolReferences array

findings: Valid JSON syntax with proper structure and formatting
Consistent data types: integers for IDs, strings for names and descriptions
Logical object relationships maintained throughout
No orphaned references or broken internal links
Array structures properly formatted and accessible
issues: 4-point deduction for inconsistent field naming patterns (workflowId vs agentName casing)

findings: Perfect JSON syntax with hierarchical structure
Consistent naming conventions across all entities
Enhanced type safety with structured metadata
Clean separation of concerns through object containers
No structural inconsistencies or validation errors

reasonsForDeductions: Semantic Similarity (-8 points): Field name changes (workflowId->id, agentName->name) may cause semantic confusion during migration transitions
Structural Similarity (-22 points): Major architectural changes including root structure reorganization, array renaming (nodes->workflowAgents), and complete tool reference mechanism redesign
AAVA 1.0 Correctness (-4 points): Inconsistent field naming conventions mixing camelCase patterns (workflowId vs agentName)

recommendations: Implement field mapping logic for renamed properties (workflowId->id, workflowName->name, agentName->name)
Create structural transformation utilities to convert flat 'nodes' arrays to hierarchical 'workflowAgents' structure
Develop tool reference migration scripts to handle tools->toolReferences conversion
Update all dependent systems to handle new workFlowDetail container structure
Modify agent processing logic to work with enhanced metadata (agentId, modelDeploymentName)
Implement backward compatibility layer during transition period
Create comprehensive test suites covering both AAVA 1.0 and 2.0 processing
Implement schema validation for both versions during migration period
Establish data integrity checks for field mapping accuracy
Document all field mapping relationships for future reference
Create migration guides for development teams
Establish version control practices for metadata schema evolution

recommendedApproach: Phased migration with parallel processing support during transition period
